Dear Ms. Smith:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
May 15, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Six foster care case records were reviewed, (one of seventeen updated services plans)
reviewed was late, the report dated 12/6/22 – 3/5/23 submitted on 3/7/23 was 1 day late.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM INTERIM 2022
722- 08D Treatment Plan: Agreement and signatures
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain signatures
from the following individuals, as applicable: caseworkers, supervisors,
second line supervisor, when siblings in care are place apart. Parents who
are a member of a participating household, youth ages14 or older, foster
parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardian, youth and caregivers must check yes or no for the
following when signing the treatment plan: I have participated in the
development of the Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment
Plan.
2

Six foster care case records were reviewed, (ten of fifteen PATP’s) reviewed, two PATP was
not uploaded and/or the PATP’s were missing signatures from the caregivers, parents, and/or
the boxes were not check indicating participation with the treatment plans.
801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child’s
current and complete health information.
One of six foster care case files reviewed did not have current and complete health
information documented quarterly on the medical passports.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• 400.12409 Education
The agency was advised to make sure the youth’s name is on the report
cards and education documents.
400.12404 Placement
The agency was advised to have an individual photo of the youth in care
opposed to a group photo.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• No Consultation was provided.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
3

The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. Two
special investigations and one interim inspection. Special
Investigation#2022C0420022 was generated on 5/23/22. The agency was in
violation with R400.12713, Adoption Placement Record, the CAP was completed
on 7/28/2022. The agency is following their CAP and this was verfied by
reviewing documentation/forms that are kept in the director’s office with dates and
signatures and reported on the Consultant follow-up contact sheet. Special
Investigation #2022C0201015, was generated on 5/5/2022, and the CAP was
approved on 8/11/2022. The agency was in violation with Rule400.12215
Compliance with 1975 PA 238. The agency is following their CAP and this was
verfied by reviewing documentation/forms, posting on the agency walls and small
cards provided to the foster parents. This information is kept in the director’s office
with dates and signatures of staff trainings. This information is vertified and
reported on the Consultant follow-up contact sheet. The Interim Inspection report
was completed on 3/29/2022, and the CAP was approved on 4/1/2022. The
agency was in violation with Rules 400.12413, 400.12418, ISEP 4.22, DHHS
policies Fom 722.6B, 722-08C, 722.8E, and ADM 300. Overall, the agency is
working with their CAP as this reporting period, they only had one repeat violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The CA reported the prior CAP was not consistently implemented and followed by
staff, supervisors, and directors. The agency had a high turnover rate this pass
year with foster care workers, supervisors, and directors leaving abruptly. The CA
reported that each of the turnovers caused for case management issues regarding
continuity of care and timeliness of policy and rule requirements being completed
as new workers were learning their cases. Items were not being tracked as they
should have been causing late deadlines. Moving forward, the agency has hired
staff in all positions, trainings is occurring daily of the staff responsibilities,
requirements for documentation as well as utilizing time management for
completion of required workload. Staff are also working with smaller workload
numbers.
Financial Overview
The agency provided their annual budget. A copy of the nonprofit tax return from
the previous fiscal year was reviewed. The agency also had their annual audit
and it was reviewed.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff had all good feedback about the agency and the support they are provided
by their current administrative team and supervisors. The only suggestion made
was that the staff would like for the administrative staff to remain stable and
consistent.
No youth were interviewed other than the ones in the Analyst report.
Description of Agency Walk Through
4

The agency had one safety issues.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The agency had one safety alert: The unlicensed relative has a bed in the basement
and there is not a means of egress. The unlicensed relative sleeps in the basement.
Resolution: Currently there is not an alternative place for the unlicensed relative to
sleep. All safety precautions are being taken. A safety plan was implemented and
signed by the unlicensed relative. A training was held to review the bedroom
basement that includes how to navigate options to avoid use of a bedroom in the
basement. Safety alert and safety training sheets were attached to the alert for
resolution compliance.
RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Ennis for Children – Port Huron continue on their regular
license.
